Now, I bought this game back in 2009. Yes, bought. $50, spent another $10 for 30 days of action district time. I had managed to obtain 6 months worth of action district time by selling Portal themed vehicles in the marketplace for subscription currency (it wasn't illegal, they had actually made a system for it). When this game was revived by GamersFirst, all of us who bought this game retail only got our original characters back as compensation. But... all of our character stats had been wiped. Why am I telling you this? So you'll be surprised to say that, despite being screwed over, this game is still addictive and fun enough to still jump back in and play from square one. Its an exceptionally fun game if you play with a good group of friends or a clan and use voice communication as well. Tactical team gameplay is a must for this game. If you have a coordinated team of players who use excellent gameplay tactics, you will hardly ever lose. A recommended download.

I recommend this with the stipulation that your computer is better than average. This is a performance-intensive game, but it is worth it. The city of San Paro is beautiful, and the customization options you have for your characters and vehicles are remarkable. When a massive traffic jam causes problems, it can make for engaging gameplay - or it can bog down a subpar RAM setup.  It's a freemium game that under-delivered on the promises made by the original APB. While it is not a perfect game by any stretch, the interactions and gunfight scenarios available to you in the given setting are fantastic. This was GTA Online before there was a GTA Online. It's worth trying, at the very least.

APB Reloaded is personally one of my favourite game. You can customise your character and your car! The guns are quite well-balanced.  However, there are many issue that is a hinderance to the game. Such examples will be unstable latency where if you stay in a country far from the server, you will not be able to move your character and shoot smoothly as people who stay in the country that has the server. Another problem is the premium guns where some free-players and beginners will find themselves in a serious disadvantage compared to premium players who has wide range of guns suited to their situations.  APB is one of those games where it feels good to play at first, but as times goes on, you will find yourself in a battle of keeping your interest alive of playing the game.  I give this a 5/10.   -Kiro

The most armas weapons are too strong like the 'scout' ,a new sniper rifle, you can shoot perfectly with it in the air you can use it outta a car and you can run with it...lets look on the free 2 play sniper rifle you cant do jumpshot you cant fire outta a car you cant run with it and the fire slower then the premium ones...but the biggest problem of the game is: that the gold players ( the strongest players haha ) play on the silver destricts or on bronze so you have no chance against some overpowered players who kick you out of the match in your own destrict...everything what i can say is: stay away from this game if you cant play in a team and if you wont pay money to win.

Dont let the 35 hours fool you, I've been playing for some time long before the game has been out on steam.  Probably the greatest character customization I've seen to this date, players progressively unlock premade designs or simple shapes they use to design their own, it all depends on a players imagination on how much or what their character is wearing, along with how it all looks on them, the same goes for vehicles.  Weapon and vehicle viriety isn't all that bad, you're given some basic weapons and can later aquire some with mods and some with open slots for mods which have their own ups and downs; But weapons that players can pay real money for arent available to other players; some which, while not completely better than others, the situation they cover are more common than not, You're given a small Sadan but later on you can aquire different, faster, stronger, higher storage capacity cars and some for up to 4 people can shoot out of while on the move.  Player base wise, the game seems to consist of nothing but GIFTs, short for Greater Internet â¥â¥â¥â¥wad Theory, in which a Normal Person + Anonymity + Audience = Total â¥â¥â¥â¥wad, expect to get a bunch of vile /whispers because someone that cant aim for â¥â¥â¥â¥ misses point blank with a high power sniper rifle with a slow rate of fire and you can nicely ventilate them with an automatic assault shotgun.  Driving in the game is rather floaty and awkward there is tad of a delay between the command and the vehicle doing the action. Guns have great sound but shooting pretty much forces players to aim down sights or in this game 'marksmanship mode' even in small street alleys at all times unless its an smg or some pistols, Time to kill in the game feels rather quick, dying between two or five hits depending if the weapon is a powerful hitter or a bullet hose, that along with the lack luster accuracy even in marksmanship mode means players wil spray entire magazines into each other until someone dies and getting a nice little whisper from the other player that you're a â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ or a hacker.  Finally the game has a sadly pants-on-head â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ way of choosing which server or 'district' you're forced to enter and who your enemies and allies are. A players Rank increases constantly, this would be your constantly progressing level and your Threat Level is how challenging the game perceives you, devided into Green, Bronze, Silver and Lastly Gold. the latter is sadly what the game keeps in mind about a player, districts are mainly devided by your Threat Level, so imagine a Golden Threat Rank 25 up against a Golden Threat Rank 150.   The game has a nice soundtrack, you can even play music from your MP3 library in the game if you wish, and players with that song can also hear it playing, you can also make a nice little 8-16 bit tune that will play for the player you've killed and play at the end of a round if you're the MVP.  All in all, if the game wasn't chock full of immature â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥s, guns that aren't accurate unless you're using the one sniper rifle available in marksmanship mode, crouched and still and player characters that die in 2-5 shots with no headshots to count I'd still play it.

I love Fallen Earth! So many great memories in this game. I downloaded it in 2012 and deeply regret that I missed its early days. I still play it pretty regularly, but I can't willingly recommend it.   The player base is dwindling due to lack of advertising, non-existent updates, and what seems like complete abandonment from GMs/Devs. Every anniversary that I have in memory was met with a celebration for making another great year! And if you were subscribed you would receive an article of clothing with the game's name, usually. This year, (marking Fallen Earth's seventh) there were only three redeem codes to celebrate it. Just depressing.  I unfortunately can't see a future for this game, if this continues. Recommending Fallen Earth is just letting gamers waste time, effort, and money for a game on its last leg. It pains me to write this because I don't want this game to end, but have no power to change its fate.

Here are my thoughts about this game. With the the new engine update coming out the game will now have things open to it that it did not before, with a better engine not only means better graphics but the potentital to expand into something new and refreshing.  The game is good and it's been good to me for a sold 2-3 years now, now I've had my fair share of breaks, trust me. However, there is no other game that can compete with this in terms of customization. That is the sole reason I come back to this game everytime. The customization is so in depth that it makes MMORPG's with their super detailed character creation look like child's play. (Opinion)   Yes there are flaws in the games mechanics that could use some work, but if you look past that and focus on the game itself, it's a great game with lots of potential to grow yet.

This is one of those subscription games that had to go free-to-play because they couldn't convince people to keep giving them money, and it shows. The controls are clunky: you have to go through 2-3 menus every time you want to change anything. Anything at all. The vehicles maneuver not quite as well as a fat dog on a trampoline. The player base is one of the worst I've ever seen with regards to team killing 'for lulz' and just congenital inability to cooperate. If you've got your heart set on playing a free shooter with some vehicles, download Planetside 2. Even as flawed as that game is you'll enjoy yourself a whole lot more.

This game has its own unique charm. I mainly played it when it was a P2P payment model. It has gotten a lot better and is unfortunatly under-rated. Although it still has some of its issues with animations and what not there is something that sparkles in this MMO's eyes. The crafting is genius and sometimes it feels like im in a real open world experience. Its built well to immerse you out of the MMO feel and not in a bad way. The combat is fun since you can approach it many different ways. Again with the crafting, its amazing.   There is absoultely nothing as satisfying as crafting your first ATV. Its a pinnacle moment of â¥â¥â¥â¥ yeah im bad. Another thing i really like is the no class style along with the in depth RPG elements. Im not really a fan of no class MMO's but it works perfect for Fallen Earth. My main issues with the game is for some people it can be somewhat confusing although the new tutorial is really helpful. I hope the community welcomes people who try the game with open arms. It would be a shame if it ever got shut down. City of Heroes was a tragic loss in all honesty for the MMO genre and would equally be so if Fallen Earth was to. Remember FE players, never make the new guys hate the game because you want to be an Eliteist and call the noobs and what not. That helps games die away.   All in all. My experience with FE has been one of a kind. Im going to give it another go with the F2P and see where i can go all over again. If you havent tried it, give it a go. Its worth getting into. It will seem odd and wierd at first but once you get used to it you will discover the genius behind this game.

While this game does stand out in so many ways from others, it is flunked and here's why  The good : Best customization I've seen on any game - Fun gameplay ( even though it is super frustrating at times ) - Decent Graphics for the time - Is free - and is FUN  the bad / ugly: In my 5-6 Years of gaming, Never in my LIFE have I ever seen such terrible matchups. When open conflict district came out, I was surprised when I realized that the matchmaking isn't completly random, Only 3 major threats which is â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥. Your 4 man crew which may have total of 100 hours ( all 4 guys combined ) WILL get setup against another 4 man crew of max ranks, each having 2500+ hours each. How is this balanced? Not to mention the prices are thru the â¥â¥â¥â¥ING roof. 80$ for an outfit and a car bodykit. Seriously? I can buy two copies of GTA v for that. The game is SORTA dead. In 2013, Obeya, the most popular server had 5000-7500 Players at peak hours. Now, Obeya has about 1300 peak hours. Colby, the most unpopular server, has about 200 on at peak hours. The game is BRUTAL towards noobs, mostly due to the fact that decent players ( Who are actually silver threat ) get gold SOOO easily and purposely have to dethreat to fight silvers, Leaving no room for the bronzes to learn. There aren't as many hackers anymore thanks to fairfight, but since there are rerolls due to the fact that the game is free, PUNKBUSTER IS NONEXSISTENT and has no banned one single cheater. This game is a free fast-paced FPS with mostly ballistic weapons and awesome movement mechanics including jetpacks and a complete friction loss from the ground. And because gliding + hills + speed + ballistic weapons = hard to hit, this game is difficult. And awesome. Now to get a little more precise, the movement can be compared with the little iOS game tiny wings, where you slide through the little gaps between round hills and fly around as fast as you can, but this is 3D. The weapons are mostly in one of these 3 categories: Explosive weapons fire slowly, have rather slowly flying projectiles with splash damage and extreme damage on a direct hit, while bullet based guns (autos) fire rather fast flying little projectiles dealing high damage per second if you manage to hit all shots and the usually weakest but easy to aim hitscan weapons, which work as all guns do in 'modern shooters'. You point at an enemy and when you click, they die. As you may have guessed, to be good at the game you should be able to handle guns from the first category, which are the way it's meant to be played and the only real honorable option (Debatable, I know, discuss it on reddit or whatever). The fast movement is hard to control in the beginning and hitting fast people with ballistic weapons can be extremely hard. This is what puts game's skill ceiling so high. The community is not as big as it used to be, by now the game is slowly dying (  http://steamcharts.com/app/17080#All  ). Still, there's always enough EU servers filled to join in a suitable game for me, so I will be enjoying the game for a long time. The good players are friendly to each other, the few toxic parts of the community are found in low-level servers and quit plaing sooner or later. Your first matches will be on these novice servers, although you will soon reach level 10 just to be thrown into games with the seasoned veterans when you know little about the game but the basics. This makes it even harder for new players.  So, to come to a conclusion: The game is awesome, but difficult. We can use more new players learning with each other instead of getting wrecked by pros, so give it a try. What you can have for free is one of the best multiplayer shooters out there. Prepare to get owned! Don't be frustrated, it's bound to happen. Continue playing and think about what you do, learn from the enemy and you will get better.  Have fun!

So much wasted potential, but still such a gem of a game. If you can get past the flaws it's an amazing game. The customization is unrivaled, character, clothing, cars, graffiti, and minor gun skinning. I personally enjoy the combat system. There are quite a few guns to choose from and each performs well within its niche, and the most of the 'pay to win' guns are re-skins of in-game unlockables.  System reqs:    You can play this game alright on a dual core with 4-6 gb of ram and a 1gb video card, but your experience will suffer greatly. My personal reccomendation: Quad code cpu 8gb ram 2gb or greater gpu 64 bit OS -my build for reference-    i5-3570k @ 4.5 ghz 8 Gb ddr3 @ 1866 Nvidia GTX 660 DCU II       I'm going to go ahead and insert my  tl;dr  here.  Good game overall. Small problem with hackers, free game.. (more than you know, less than you think). Customization makes this game a  must try .      Contd...  There are only two 'large' scale mission maps, they've been around since day one. Though it does get old, they really are great maps. Some mission locations can be one sided, but the overall feel of them is balanced. Now, on to the fight club maps. There are three total 'Fight Club' maps, with only two of them being active. Baylan Shipping and Storage is a small-mid size map with lots of high vantages and low cover. This map is great for any class, but is usually dominated by snipers. Asylum, it finally happened.. Asylum was originally supposed to be a kind of faction specific social district... long story. Asylum is technically still being developed for a yet to be released game-mode, but is an amazing indoors close-quarter to mid-range combat map. Then there's Beacon, the inactive map. Beacon was originally released with Baylan, but was temporarily de-activated in favor of Asylum. Nobody knows if or when it will come back, but it's mainly a close-quarters pointman map. Finally, there's Social District. Social is, as in many games, separate experience from the other districts. There are often many public conversations and arguments going on at once, some with roots going back to closed beta. Beyond that are the customization booths. There are booths for writing your own songs, writing your own death theme your vanquished opponent will hear, customizing symbols (for many purposes), vehicle customization (uses symbols), and character customization (can use symbols). There is also an in-game marketplace where players can sell their custom creations to others. That's as long-winded as I can handle tonight. Maybe one day I'll revise it.

awefull balance on top of P2W and cancerous community.  Amazing character creation system, spoiled by the terrible actual gunfights where if you dont submitt to the meta of the game (tank LMG, or clotting SMGs/shotguns/RPGs.) then you will always be at a disadvantage.  Game developers are cancer with the players, constantly worsening the game and adding in just more pay to win aspects to the shop, all of which cost about $30-40 just for a permanent single weapon. Having added almost no extra maps besides 2 small arena modes and 2 open conflict (kill on sight) versions of the already present ones.  No graphical updates, and the only vehicle diversity among players you'll see or hear is either loud crotch grabbing rap music or â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ over compensating short â¥â¥â¥â¥ metal/hard rock with only either Humvee vehicles to troll payers with ramming outside of missions, or a mustang based car thats only got speed on its side.  Faction balance is also thrown away, enforcers seem to be a high risk, high reward play style, with the only way to gain money being missions or alot from arrests. You can earn money through impounding stolen vehicles and evidence delivery or witnessing but good luck as most players on criminals are smart to remain unwitnessable and rarely use any vehicle but their own unless they are new, making enforcer faction practically impossible to earn a decent cash sum up on unless you get good gear. On the other hand criminals can get money practically anywhere, and can reach a $1000-2000 bounty extremely quickly, before being unwitnessable by just â¥â¥â¥â¥ing away from normally quiet areas. Giving criminals an almost endless suply of cash when needed, as well as having the population majority based there. (probably due to that.)  You know how i mentioned arresting criminals in apb as an enforcer? Good luck as well, without the stun shotguns or the taser you stand no chance from premium weapons or rather really any guns. The AR based one requires 7 hits of a 20 round magazine and when players are jumping and running speedy gonzales, then your bound to have almost no spare ammo.  The character customization is amazing, and personally this game's selling point, but again, its squandered by the fact that you cant unlock anything clothing wise fast enough to expand customization. Though if your a good artist you can make a pretty penny from the marketplace from your clothing creations, and probably could turn a profit that way.   The map lay outs and draw distance is honestly some of the worst i've seen. The draw distance has only ever gotten worse becuase people complained about snipers, now its at 100 meters, where litterally any pistol could outgun you, so the only 'snipers' you'll see are corner peekers and jump shooters. When this game has so many potential campaing spots with hard to reach manners, and dont give me the anti-camp â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥t. Its a legitimate defense strategy in video games if given the option, you complaining about it is the same thing as the allies saying â¥â¥â¥â¥ you to germany during WW1 for using submarines when it was a practical and obvious choice for the war of attrition.  On top of the draw distance all the mission lay outs are CQC based, litterally no sniping spots are able to oversee the positions of objectives, and this brings me to another major flaw:  THE RED â¥â¥â¥â¥ING NAME TAG. AT THE MAX DRAW DISTANCE your given an extremely bright, red, nametag thats litterally visible to everyone even looking around, and this litterally makes it impossible to flank, snipe, or even set up actual good coordinated stationary defensive ambushes.  I do like one aspect of the gameplay and its that the minimap is only gunfire, and audio based. You will not see enemies on the minimap if they make no noise, or are not spotted (good luck not being spotted for reason above.)  The ranking system for pvp is also â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥t, golds can ACTIVELY put themselves lower rank, thus fighting people litterally lower tier than them, think of CSGO an global elite versus new players to the game. Which msot of the time you wont see green tier servers (which are the only locked ones.) having player counts enough to support new players healthily.  The vehicle handling on almost every early-mid tier vehicle is â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥, and delayed. Taking a full second to actrually obey a command to turn or such, the only exception is fast cars, which leads me to believe its speed based. Meaning all those mustang based car users (forgot actual name.) are, again, getting the best â¥â¥â¥â¥ in the game.   I give this game a 2/10.  I'll only rarely even think of touching this game, and thats mostly for customization amazingness, but like i said, thats really its only selling point. BF: HARDLINE Was legitimately better than this game in every field but its Dead on PC, the only reason this isnt the case is everyone loves the customization thats never present in any other shooter. That and the P2W buddies are willing to spend hundreds and hundreds of dollars on their OP weapons which the devs refuse to nerf. (check the forums, youll never see patch notes for weapons that involving decreasing or increasing any stats unless they are sniper rifles or other weapons that are never used. The AK47 (N-tec) was one of the only competitive rifles to use against SMGs and they nerfed its tap fire, but they havent even touched the commonly used p2w weapons.)  My recomendation for improvement: Kill this game, and actively dont play any gamers-first games, if we're lucky theyll do a 180 turn and actrually balance it once they see profits go down (this is what happens with games like warface which was a notoriously bad P2W before finally shaping up and are now semi-decent F2P games.).  Otherwise, i dont see hope for this game. Its loosing a small amount of players every 2 weeks, which is honestly a good sign, and it finally lost its positive status which was litterally just people trying to sympathize with the game due to its character creation aspects and unique cops vs criminals....or nostalgia. All of which never address the issues of the game or handling balance issues seriously enough.

It's a great game, the pewpew action is very satisfying. The sound is absolutely incredible! And i'm always a sucker for games with the level of customization that APB has. However: The hacking is absolutely ridiculous. It takes two shots to kill someone with a sniper rifle, but people will kill you with two bullets from a side arm. Then there's the ability to shoot through walls (not as bad as CS used to be). Many times i will hit the wall I'm hiding behind, with half my body exposed. But other people will have barely a head showing, and waste you.   I try to play bad, so I can go back down in threat, where the hackers are not prominent. But it's tedious. If you can tolerate the hacks, it's a great game. I will unlikely spend money on this until they fix that. I'd uninstal entirely, but my character looks badass.

APB Reloaded is, in my experience, a good and fun concept gone wrong. Server lag hits often, meaning that only people who pay for top-notch internet can keep going without any interruptions. The matchmaking system is undeniably the worst I have ever seen. 10 minutes in and I get thrown into a match with people who have nothing but machine guns that can blow up my car in less time than I can react, and even if I'm outside of a car, that thing can still rip me a new one while I still have my stock assault rifle. I've heard about cheaters and hackers, but I don't recall ever encountering one, though it's hard to tell when many weapons are essentially 2-4 shot kills. The weapons are good and do their job right. The assault rifles are neither good nor bad at anything in particular, the shotguns are guarunteed kills at close range, snipers are excellent at long range. But the machine guns, those things are over powered. As stated before, the machine guns can destroy vehicles in about 2 or 3 seconds of sustained fire. Most people cruise around in their stock cop/criminal cars which can't withstand too much fire and end up dead. They also have insane range and accuracy. The only weakness I've heard about them is that they suffer an absolutely terrible drop in accuracy when moving, but it doesn't seem to be as bad as it claims since I've been bum rushed by several people who just spray-n-pray. The only thing good about the game is the game modes and progression system, but with the problems I mentioned before one would have to take this with a mountain of salt. Like I said at the begginning of my review, it's a good concept that suffers from bad design and maintenance.

Well that was 3.7 hours I'm never getting back.  APB, apparantly, was once a brilliant open-world game with players joining the ranks of either the police force or the criminal thugs as they battle it out in gamemodes and on the streets. However, it went horribly wrong at some point and now we are left with this mess.  APB was and still is an open world shooter with missions, ranks and unlocks, and granted, I enjoyed my first hour or so customising my thug to be what I liked to call 'Bootleg Batman'. I had read the reviews saying that its horrible and its 'A good game gone bad', but I was willing to give it a go.  My first hour went something like this, I opened the game and was greeted with a character customisation screen. I've always been a sucker for customisation options so I was eager to get started. When I did eventually finish I got into the game, did the tutorial (there wasn't much of one anyway) and drove my car around. I began looting shops for the next hour and then I decided it was a good idea to do a mission. How wrong I was.  The mission went horribly. The people against us had overpowered rifles and rocket launchers, and they just ploughed through our cars like they were made of tinfoil. After this, I came to the conclusion that it was just a fluke, an unlucky game. I tried a few more, it was the same thing. I did this about 10 times before giving up entirely.  My point is, is that there is no balance system, so noobs and general idiots don't get cut any slack. Not to mention the disgustingly cancerous community. I'm pretty sure I became a tumour after I was finished with this game, it was either Russian fetuses shouting â¥â¥â¥â¥ â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ or some idiot blaming everyone but himself for not winning, and don't even get me started on the open world trolls. You cant even walk 6 feet without getting your brains splattered all over the badly textured walls by some sniper that's half way across the small 'open world' map.  To finish off, don't get this, don't think of it, don't even think of thinking of it, otherwise you will get tumours. Either that or you'll play long enough to become the tumours.  tl:Dr here:  Pros:   Customisation system, and a good one too, its fleshed out and you can customise all of your car and your clothing  Cons:   No balancing system, low levels get the benefit of losing their faces to high level sniper rifles repeatedly  The cars handle horribly, its like I driving on ice  The textures are terrible  Cancerous community, take your pick from Russian fetuses, 6 year old idiots and human swear machines  Trolls (also cancerous, but deserves its own listing), snipers camp the  rooftops rocket launcher guys stalk the ground, and smell the fresh noob meat.  Grindfest, takes a week to get anything of value.     Just, don't bother with this.

I want to like this game. It has the potential to be fun. It's mechanics are great. The idea behind it amazing. But alas, it lacks the one thing any PVP game requires: Balance. It advertises a tutorial server that doesn't exist, so you're tossed into the thick of things to learn the game. It doesn't tell you controls, mission types, or anything of the sort, and the worst of it all is the utter lack of balance. A fresh off the boat character will be matched against gold level players wielding rocket launchers and LMG's that may as well be classified as ranged chainsaws. It's not newbie friendly at all, and it doesn't give you a chance to learn the game before putting you against people who live and breath the game. I can't recommend this, as much as I want to enjoy it.

This game took me a little bit to get used to, I am very glad I took the extra time and didnt just stop because now I really enjoy this game. I have put in a decent amount of hours into the game, and I have really become addicted to it. Great crafting set up, decent amount of story type missions for you to do, and actually a pretty friendly community. There are a few things that could really be worked on that I will mention but for the most part a great game.  I very much like the crafting, and sometimes find myself staying in the same shop crafting for hours. You could pretty much completely stay away from anything mission or town wise and be completely happy making yourself food to keep healed up, or use your wide range of healing abilities. You cant completely do that though, there are a few different items that you can not craft, that you would have to get lucky on a drop with or buy from a merchant. From what I have seen you dont get chips(credits) from loot drops though, it seems to come from missions or selling your drops.  The two things that I have noticed that needs improvement are the enemy AI, you can almost walk five feet away from them and have them not notice you at all. The other thing is some of the vagueness on missions. There is not a lot of detial with some of the missions, some of them you really do need to just figure out on your own or ask the help channel for any input.  All and all, I do very much like this game and see myself playing for awhile.

I first played Tribes: Ascend 3 or 4 years ago on its official site I got hooked to it pretty fast and it even became one of those games that you could play and forget a little thing called the time. The game is really fast paced for those of you that have not played it reccomend that if you are the type of gamer that can lose there temper very easily on an online game and you like to blame it on lag then this would not be the game for you simply cause most of the players Have mastered the tragectory system meaning that they could probably predict where you are going to land or where you are going to run or ski off to and shoot a grenade at your feet from across the map. Now when i stopped playing this game my old computer fryed itself and i nearly got completly got engrossed in consol games and had completly forgot about tribes until a few days ago but could not remember the name at all until a friend that played it before said it was on steam. Now while i was downloading this i thought my preowned Toshiba laptop that i got for less than Â£200 wont be likley to handle this at all well tribes proved me wrong it has never lagged on me at all so far and i find that outstanding considering that TF2 lags all the time until ive been on the server for a few minutes. I feel that its unfortunate that the communilty of tribes ascend has remained so small cause if it got pretty big we would be looking at one of the biggest free to play fps games competing alongside tf2 which wasnt even originally free and many more. Ive noticed that they have only updated a couple of times since they brought the game out to the online comunity and ive also seen people question or speculate on it but i say where did they need to improve. Now i noticed that they reduced the blast radius and damage of explosives and I would suggest a tribe customization and that would represent the players clan. But please HiRez Studios if any of you read this review please only take the suggestion if there is a boost on players in the steam and web community. The game of great promises, greater disappointment and epic development fail. The game that's supposed to be every little boy's cops-n-robbers dream come true. However because of poor managment not only did it sink the company behind it, but even under the wings of a new owner people connected with the development process, being it developers or community managers, either got fired a few times or quit on their own.  The game is extremly newbie unfriendly, the weapon/shooting/engagement mechanics are so weird that the experience gained in other FPS/TPS games doesn't carry well into this one. There's a tutorial (finally, after being worked on for about 1,5 year or so), but it doesn't teach you anything that will help you to survive against hardened old timers of San Paro, because let's face it - the only people left still playing this game are the ever so bitter die-hards, that are so addicted, they won't let go. Be advised, you'll be facing them often, and when you do, they'll pull every dirty trick in the book, do anything and everything in their power to make your stay in San Paro as miserable and frustrating as they are.  So is this game this bad? That's a trick question. There's this really nice matchmaker feature that should match you up against people of simmilar skill level. It should, but currently the population pool is so low that the matchmaker has some real proplems finding the right people, so don't be surprised if a lot, if not most, of your missions are extremely one-sided. And most often you'll be on the wrong side.  APB is also the only game I ever played in which just driving around the map during the mission and â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ off your opponents can be way more fun than actually playing the game like it was meant.  It's also the only game that ups its hardware requirements bit by bit with each patch. I remember the times when I could record the game in 60FPS, 800x500, while running the game in 60FPS HD with highest detail settings and antialiasing. I don't know what went wrong, but the last time I ran it, I could barely get 45FPS on medium settings.  The greatest power of this game is that it's one of a kind, there's really no other like it. All the shooting and driving, and shooting while driving, car chases, skirmishes, sudden twists... all of this is great fun... until you get screwed either by being matched against a group of four teamspeaking clannies that will â¥â¥â¥â¥ you silly, or just the game itself, like: â¢ being spawned 150m from the objective while the opposing team spawns right next to it, â¢ being spawned in some sh!thole where the civilization suddenly died and noone owned a car, with the closest car spawner farther than the objective itself, â¢ the objective spawning in a place thats nearly impossible to storm when properly defended, ofcourse with the enemy already guarding it â¢ general respawn mechanics - missions get won or lost because of it. â¢ weird camera workings, which results in your toon often obstructing whatever you're aiming at, â¢ bugs that remain unfixed to this day, â¢ so you just switched to your sniper rifle? Nice, but now the fight moved to a close quartes area, take your precious mission time and switch again; you did? Great, but we could use a sniper now... ... I could go on like this. There are just so many gameflow breaking faults of random annoyance that at some point you're so fed up with the game that you quit... only to go back two weeks later to have a lot of fun and then suddenly being reminded what â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ you so much in this game, and you quit again... this love-hate relationship may go on for a while, but at some point you grow the maturity to finally quit, uninstall and never look back.  Currently the game dies little by little with the population systematically shrinking each month. There's a (supposedly) big update coming up (that's been delayed 2 years already) which will replace the dated, old, heavily customized Unread Engine with a 'factory issue' Unreal 3 engine (if I remember correctly). A lot of people bound great hopes with this event, however, as devs stated, the new engine will bring a bit better graphics and will allow to bring more content to the game a lot easier and faster. By more content I understand probably more guns, cars and clothing which will be sold thru ARMAS - the ingame cash shop. IMHO APB doesn't need more content, as it won't fix the game's fundamental issues, frustrating gameflow breakers and dangling pieces of gameplay mechanics that Real Time Worlds never managed to properly implement.  Update: G1 rolled an event that was actually worth playing so I decided to reinstall. After three hours I can clearly tell that the cheating is out of hand. Each mission in which I participated had at least one gold-threat low-rating player (which indicates a freshly created account) in both teams, running around in newbie clothes kicking everyone's â¥â¥â¥ sky high. Go figure. Plus, old bugs, like the scoreboard bug (players from previous missions in current mission scoreboard, so you can't tell who're you up against) still not fixed. There's just absolutely no fun left in this game what so ever. No engine update is gonna save this burning trainwreck.

This game has been out for a while, and, compared to other currently active MMOs, Fallen Earth does fairly well.  If you like the post-apocalpytic theme, crafting a variety of items, shooter action-rpgs, and playing with others, you should enjoy this one.  The aesthetics are pretty good, the equip-able armor and weapons are all visible on your character. The music and sounds are decent.   The controls are easy to familiarize yourself and, like most MMOs, the beginning tutorial is extremely helpful in establishing your bearings in the game world. The learning curve is moderate to challenging, depending on how familiar you are with MMORPGs and their mechanics.  Crafting is a very fun part of this game if you are into that - you can craft almost anything you see in the game world (which beats having to spend your resources on merchants. Within the first 2 hours I already was driving around in my own ATV. The gameplay is pretty good, however, it still remains fairly buggy in many areas. The AI has godlike sensors, able to detect and chase you across the map once you have aggro'd (hostile interaction) them.   Grinding in this game is actually pretty fun considering that the rewards are very reasonable and the variety in missions is very, very good - they aren't 90% fetch or find quests typical of many MMORPGs. Combat can be weird and clunky at times, and hopefully this will be improved, however, it has been a long time and these problems still remain.  If you can look past these bugs, and enjoy grinding and crafting in the post-apocalyptic setting, then give this game a try.   Recommend.

It is not impossible to do well in this game without paying real $$, it is however very difficult. The only reason this game has not faded into obscurity is because it has a great customization suite that allows for your characters to truly be unique. The mechanics and gunplay are addicting but the issues with a competitive 3rd person perspective will occasionally leave you frustrated. GamersFirst really needs to reevaluate its monetization policy and look at maybe moving away from pay to win. Depending on the server you play on, script kiddies will be an issue, the game is 'free to play' which means you have people creating new accounts as soon as they get banned. Overall the game has its issues but for me its redeeming qualities outshine its issues. With all that said, this game is definitely not for everyone, but as it is free to play I recommend that everyone tries it out, this game could use a larger population. I have about 2000 hrs total playtime (before steam integration) and I can firmly say that its potential is being squandered by GamersFirst. IF changes come about, I could realistically see this game become a huge hit for more than the small number of people who play it nowadays.

I have been playing this game ever since early 2011, and still to this day the events are epic and the updates are frequent. The game used to be owned by RealTime Worlds but then was bought by Gamersfirst, ever since then the games performance was dropped significantly. The servers are more unstable, they crash a half a dozen times weekly, and recently while I was online the servers completely froze for a good half a minute. The chat was flooding with complaints from players but it was pretty funny if you ask me. Hackers are uncommon on this game which is good.  A few of the reasons why I still continue to put up with this game is because of the player freedom and community. The character customization is very complex. For example, there are like 4 different customization sliders just for your characters nose. The clothing and character customization is so vast that I have seen players in-game dressed as Ronald Mc'Donald, The Joker, Harly Quinn, celebreties such as Justin Bieber, Tupac, Will Smith, Bill O'Reilly, Obama, Chuck Testa, Youtubers, and many more.  The vehicle customization is also huge and with certain vehicle modifications, such as Nitro 3, you can do stunts and jumps in a district and impress some people.   The game is very unique as far as the character customization and free roam aspect. I'd give it a 7.5/10 due to the servers preformance and the fact that many people get falsely banned quite frequently due to 3rd party programs when they never even did anything wrong. I'v lost friends that have just one day disapeared from this happening to them, it's depressing that the G1 staff don't help at all when it comes to unbanning. If you get banned on this game permanently for any reason at all, don't expect on getting it unbanned.

Yep, you read it, 1879 hours!  Well, I used to like this game because I could grind and talk to friends at the same time, take over territories, and engage in awesome shootouts (PvP) with up to 20 players or more.  I really got the feeling that I was part of a team and that some people were real helpful with noobs (mainly because of the clan aspect). I had a lot of fun playing this and there are a lot of missions and content. In fact, I am still only 33% of the way through completing the achievements, albiet some of them are unobtainable now.  When the devs were active, they would appear in-game all the time to give away items and be helpful. This was great! Sometimes they would use 'god powers' to be invisible and watch us play new areas that just got released, then make private messages 'I see you!'. - HAH That's great! I met a couple devs that would recognize me and start chatting; even added me to their steam friends list. Pretty cool!  The best experience was on Halloween 3 years in a row where the devs would come out and give away treats (bling for your character). The first year, a dev transformed himself into a giant 4 story tall beast and he ATE ME! HAHAHAHahhaa So the next two years I stood in the mass crowd of online players and typed 'Turn into the beast again!' and sure enough he did, and he ate me again, and everyone started clattering their keyboards to respond. SO GREAT!  But yeah,.. it's just a ghost town now... If more people played, the devs would care again, and this game would once again bring me joy (bugs and all).

Not revamped, not rejigged, not redesigned. Reloaded. APBâs new suffix is apt, as this free-to-play reincarnation of 2010âs deflated cops and robbers MMO is a retread of the same ground. The same drab city, the same hollow combat, the same lopsided results. The original city of San Paro has been left standing, a monument to badly judged level design and the colour grey. The first gameâs devs, Realtime Worlds, intended the place to live and breathe. Instead, it spluttered a few times before its life support failed. Its resurrection is a miserable one. Reloadedâs missions usually pit two small squads of human-controlled criminals and enforcers against each other, asking them to perform a multi-stage series of mini-jobs. One team has to drive to a place, collect a thing, and deliver it somewhere else. The other team has to stop them. Occasionally this leads to the kind of scenes that flicker through the minds of non-players when you describe APB to them: high-speed chases through busy streets, lastsecond jumps into getaway cars. Most of APBâs problems remain in Reloaded. It even inherited a few new ones, as it is currently seeded with cheaters. The original game was arguably killed too soon, so the switch to free-to-play means interested parties should at least take a weekend city break back to San Paro. But this is no revitalisation â APB Reloaded is rehash, replication, and repetition.

What I love about this game is that it is much more of out smarting your opponent than having a better gun. Even though sometimes guns can be over powered, most are balanced but easily better in certain situations. But with the proper team anything can be done. This game has it's glitches though and lag but nothing game breaking in my opinion. And hey it's free. If you do put money into it though it will reward your experience.  But the gameplay isn't the only thing that makes APB special. The customization is almost limitless. I've made several characters from movies (Batman, Iron Man, Captain America, Punisher, Superman etc.) and it's a lot of fun in my opinion. The customization is way beyond most games period. If not the best.  People are trying to fix some of the problems in the game as well. We'll be due for a new engine update soon, so hopefully that will fix most of the issues.  All in all this is my all time favorite MMO. Will you like it? I have no idea, but you should try it!

I would call this game Pay to Win. Argue if you want, but it's a multiplayer PVP game for the most part and you can buy cooldowns, permanent weapons ( some with exclusive mods, ) 2.25 times more cash gains etc...  You can buy pretty much everything permanently with real money right off the bat, be it cars, weapons, etc. If you want to be 100% Free to Play, be ready to spend tons of gold on 10-days lasting weapons. You will have to gather money for days to get one permanent weapon, only if someone is selling one on the Marketplace. The community is terrible, there's many bugs, random downtimes which cancel your missions and you lose the rewards you would have gotten for that misson. Also you can slaughter the whole city and be unnoticed, but be wary that breaking a store window by mistake, not even stealing anything and the other players playing enforcers can arrest you and steal all the money you have on you!  Also the matchmaking is terrible, sometimes you get matched with 2 other silvers and you have to face 3 golds. Your whole team could be rank 20 and you play against rank 200+ which have more mods, better cars, knows the game more and have better weapons. You have ''Bronze, Silver and Gold'' servers, but they're full of golds who like to pwn noobs either way. Only the leader can call for backup and people go AFK randomly pretty often.  Also, if your team leader ( which seems to be random because 90% of the time I join a mission I am not the leader, ) decides that he dosen't like you, he can kick you right before the mission ends to make you lose all the money and experience you would've gotten. He can also kick you just because you killed him by mistake, just because you sprayed a tag before him or even because you are MVP and he wants to be MVP instead!  The good? It's probably one of the only MMO that looks like GTA and Saints Row. The graphics are ok and the game has alot of content. Sadly, it's not a game I would play more than I already did after noticing all the flaws it has.  Here's the benefit of premium ( forums says it's 12.50$ per month: )  Around 90% bonus to all Contact XP gains. +125% bonus cash gain ( Instead of 500$ for a mission you would gain 1125$. ) 20% discount on the Armas Marketplace ( Real money marketplace. ) 50% shorter cooldown on abilities like Field supplier, Nitro booster, etc. ) Deeper Customization (50 Symbols per Vehicle / Clothing items, 100 layers per Symbol. ) Removal of Subscription ADS ( which appears at the end of all missions. ) Armas Trials for weapons and vehicles last 3 hours instead of 30 minutes ( which makes using the 200~ trials, 6 times more effectively. )

Oh boy yes do I reccomend this game. The Combat system is a clever mix of Third/First Person Shooting/Melee like Skyrim or Fallout with some Tab Combat like WoW when casting Mutations (Basically spells for healing, damage and support) so you can choose to simply ignore one play style over the other or use a mix of one. If you want to dual wield two, one handed melee weapons or guns then go for it, the game allows you to even use a one handed melee and gun at the same time, basically filling melee and range in one go.  BE AWARE though that the mouse buttons are backwards, to use the weapon in your right hand click the left mouse button and vice versa. I haven't found a way to fix this without it affecting interactions with the world so my advice is don't change it.  The only flaws are the sound and beginners confusion. I personally found the ambience quite annoying and the game is very quiet out of combat but I suppose you could call it relaxing.  At the beggining of the game you follow a simple tutorial dungeon (with good voice acting) and then you get to pick one of three starter locations that tailor to how you would like to play.   You have a few starter quests which thankfully come one at a time but when you leave that slice of starter land and head into town then you'll find there are lots of quests that need doing. They don't appear very cleatly on the mini map so look hard and you'll notice little hazard symbols like the desktop icon bare visible on the mini map. Those are quest icons.  I did notice that the starter areas seem to follow a similar story at first, just in a different landscape.  One thing that really confused me was Tradeskills. I'm sure once I devote more time to the game and decide what kind of character I want to be I'll understand it better.  If you want a nice little MMO that puts the best features of WoW and Fallout into one then have a go...

Experience starting: 1: Toxic, immature playerbase rife with racial slurs and homophobia. 2: Poor balancing. First mission in the starting zone was put right in against two other players one with a grenade launcher. Not a good first experience. 3: There is no actual tutorial, you have to figure out everything for yourself, which is fine except plenty of things don't make any sense. IE you can't shoot at criminals in the midst of a crime spree unless your in their mission even though the game claims you can 'witness criminal activity with alt' to start a mission against them. Lots of unspoken rules, lots of players will lose their minds if you actually complete mission objectives. 4: Driving feels sloppy. 5: Gunplay feels weak. Headshots apprently don't count, certain weapons have so far been abysmal. Shotguns that can't kill beyond 5 feet, pistols that just can't kill even when you sneak around and initiate. Long time to kill makes the game feel like the shooter gameplay is tacked on. 6: All the guns cost money if you want them for more than ten days apparently. 7: Most of the civillians look identical. You basically have a city apparently populated by janitors and hookers who can't blink. 8: Customization has lots of options.  In all I tried to give it a fair shake but it disappointed me at most every turn. Was expecting a fun cops and robbers game where you could jump right into heists as they occur and create scenarios organically. It's meh, i've come to realize at this point this game largely filled with the aspect of P2W which is basically you buy premium and get a bonus of 100% for everything along with that hackers are known and don't get dealt with. So far i've sent in three support tickets with suspected cheaters and gave clear images along with links with there emails and names tied to hacking sites that confirm that they do pay for cheats for atleast another game at the best.   They've responded to one and still haven't replied with any others, the support ticket I was responded was a giant robotic reply which basically is summed up as the TLDR version; 'We will look into the matter, however we can't tell you anything about the player due to privacy concerns, etc, etc'. It's been 48 hours now and hes been hackusated by a entire server and multiple people accuse him of speedhacking which he abused along with his aimbot.  The P2W aspect is that for a meesly $5 you can get a Perm gun of four choices that are usually really good and do indeed own the free versions, you get a free car which is also nice along with 500 G1C credits and 31 days of membership. With that you've basically made it so you're going to outlevel normal players by atleast 60% faster and don't have to waste your money on guns and cars early rather saving up and being able to purchase the end-games guns and cars soon as they're unlocked for you. However the most P2W element is the Arma weapons themself due the fact you're able to purchase much stronger versions of the F2P guns at much lower ranks along with having unique perks such as silencers, better modifiers, etc.

This game is awful.   1. FPS mechanics are terrible, with NO HEAD HITBOXES. AWFUL HIT DETECTION. EXTREMELY LONG TTK (which would be fine if there were skill-based mechanics involved).   2. Extreme pay to win a la Asian shooter, i.e. you have to either spend all of your time playing this game, spend money, or fail to be competitive due to expiring weapons.   3. Maps and respawns were balanced by chimps. Some missions favor one side immensely over the other. Not to mention the vapid objective based gameplay.   4. Matchmaking is terrible with veterans having extreme advantages over new players with perks. Sure CoD can do this, but it doesn't make it any less stupid.   5. Cheaters abound.   6. Little variety at the core of the game which is quintessentially a few big team-based CTF flags with car chases in between. Sounds fun on paper and is fun the first 30 times, then it gets old along with the rock-paper-scissors gunplay.   The only good thing I can say about this game is that the graphics are fair and it runs.. alright. The character, car and clothes customization is amazing, along with the custom themes (music editor), but it's at the core a grindy, imbalanced collection of little CTF maps where the world around you feels fake and shallow, just like the gunplay. Ok so, where do I start? This game was a game I was very fond of (As my time spent playing it might show) and I've already written a review before but since it was kinda choppy I stepped upon it again and decided to add to it.  I've been playing this game for around 4 years back when I started around 2012 when I was also first introduced to steam, so along with downloading TF2 this game caught my eye as my love of post-apoc settings for games sparked my intrigue. Back then, this game just had so much to offer, to me in particular as I was fine with discovering most of it for myself with managing to obtain an ATV early on.   In terms of gameplay, the whole grinding aspect didn't really bother much as I was still managing to have fun cooperating with various people I would meet around placed like Embry (I think that was the name of the main S1 city?) and City where there was an event to protect a town made up by players from enemy mobs (Called Shivas If I'm correct) where you would see people showing off their cool gear and mounts.  The PvP aspect of the game was never really anything I tapped into, It just didnt really intrest me, but I'm sure theres some players out their who saw its potential.  To end this review of, no matter how bad it is, I guess this game is kinda dead with its peak being off in the earlier years where I made a few friends on my way to Lvl 55.  If anyone remembers me, my main characters name was Brad Carson, with other names like Pvt.Brad being another char of my mine, and to anyone who remembered me, It was a pleasure having played a fun game with you for quite a few years.   Sorry if this review was pretty bad, I'm just really getting over a lot.

I know the game is free. I know this. Does it mean I have to forgive it for being crap? No.  This game is exactly what I would expect from what is essentially a free-to-play Grand Theft Auto. Everything feels about ten years old, there is lag and general bugginess, and not a sh*t was given by anyone else as to whether the objectives were being carried out.  I didn't play a ton, but sometimes when you experience something, you are able to read it for the best that it could be independent of the momentary experience. This game doesn't have the capacity to entertain for the long term. Free-to-play games rarely do, though I feel I do have to mention Counter-Strike as one of a few exceptions to that rule. To be fair, though, this game is much newer than CS, and yet learns nothing from it or games like it.  This game seems more or less like a controlled environment from which get trolled other people than a legitimate attempt at entertaining; I knew that the first time that I attempted to kill the person with the briefcase, only to be shot from a vantage point directly above me that I had no hope of approaching from any other direction.  Take it for what you will - I played the game as long as I could stand to.

I'll be honest as I possibly can be with this review in particular.  The game is tough when you start out (ofcourse, because ALL games do), and when you progress on, it becomes easier. I'll say it again, tough when starting out... easier when you keep playing. The only thing that most people dont realize and should. There are also, positive and nevative things to the game (again, all games do), but to be basic, i'll narrow it down to the exact things that are good and bad about this game.  So, whats good is, theres huge customization on just characters alone, as well as symbols and audio, with its own feel for car physics and mechanics that are actually quite interresting and unique.  What is bad, is nothing of the actual game its self, but the people who play it. I wont lie, the majority of guns are quite difficult to handle, which its not that bad if you think about it, just means you need to try... since you cant win anything by doing nothing. But, the majority of people that tend to play this game on a daily basis, end up ruining it for everyone, including themselves. Stupid, is it not? Sadly, these are all of the ones who end up cheating just because they dont bother to play the game, or just do it because they feel powerful and have no actual lives to do anything but ruin things for everyone.  If you can do just one thing, maybe... just maybe, I can truely recommend this game to anyone. That one thing is: Try, without ruining everything, even for other fellow players who desperately attempt to make a good clean day of APB:Reloaded.

This game is one of the best F2P games I have ever played, and the biggest F2P game I have ever played.  +The game world is huge. It spans over sectors and the overall map is bigger then triple A titles such as GTA V and Just Cause 2.  +Character customisation. When you start the game you have the ability to change the appearance of your character, and during the game you can equip things that can add benefits and features, like dusters or combat suits.  +Clans and teams. In game there is a team system that people can join into so that you can complete a mission together, and some missions require that. The team system also allows voice chat. There is also a clan system that works like normal, and the clan has a special 'clan vault' that they can use.  +Mega server. All players are on one server, but it works due to the map size.  +Vehicles. The game has various mounts, such as horses and even giant mutated chickens, along with motorbikes, ATVs, dune buggys, and more.  -Microtransactions. Since this is a free to play game, it is a given. You can buy almost any item in the game on their store. But I do not mind doing this from time to time, as I enjoy the game to the point that I want to support it.  -Graphics. They aren't very good. Good news for people on lower end PCs like me, but for somebody running a machine that costs as much as a small family vehicle, not so much.  -Voice acting. Barely any of it... at all. It is really BAD, it just isn't common.  -Buggy. Some bugs will occur in the game, but there is usually a fix. Usually.  TL;DR: This game is a pretty fun first person post apocalyptic online RPG. Possibly the only one of its kind. If you liked Fallout, you should try it out. If you hated Fallout, you. I reccomand this game for anyone, really.

Bought APB when it originally came out, glad that's it's 'free2play', shame that it's now 'pay2win', and if you wanna win, it's not cheap. One thing I really do love in this game: Customisation. There is so much customisation in this game; customising you're custom character with custom items that can be customised with custom created patterns, that's a seriously impressive amount of customisation. Which is why I don't understand, with the wealth of cosmetic options available, why all the 'real money' items can't just be the 'cosmetic' ones. From tattoos to new hair styles to the 100's of clothing items (of which more can be created) and bazillions of combinations that this gives you, there is surely enough content there to continue to fund this game without selling overpowered weaponry. Path of Exile does it. Path of Exile doesn't even have much customisation. But no. pay2win Well, you'll have the occasional fun match with equally skilled, equally equipped players, but only 'occasionally'. More than often, you'll be pitted against player's that have forked out for the massively 'over-powered-death-weapons-of-instant-death' weaponry, and then any skill you've aquired at playing well; will mean naught. If you've just won the lottery and want to spend it in a game where overpowered weaponry destroys all form of difficulty and balance then this is for you. This game is a pretty standard example of how to milk a game for all it is worth using already existing assets.  I was an original player from back when the game was owned and run by Real Time Worlds (R.I.P) and published by EA. I was one of the first batch of players to play APB Reloaded during the closed beta period. After open beta is began it's continuous downward spiral.  Pros - Customization, it's nearly unmatched in the options for customizations  Cons - Poor community and lack of in-game moderating; griefers, hackers and inappropriate behavior that isn't punished. - Dominated by in-game microtransaction system; you'll rarely find people that play consistently who don't spend money in some form. It's not impossible to play without paying, takes a noticeable amount of time for it to be worth it. - Unoptimized. - Poor matchmaking; back during closed beta there weren't districts that were divided by 'threat level', so often times higher ranked players would get matched against many more people than were in their group. I consider that a step up to what is currently in the game. - Poor spawn system; pretty easy to push on a spawn so the enemy spawns farther away, and car spawners have completely ruined the dynamic of the game.

I am R130 ENF and R70 CRIM, this game is pretty enjoyable for me because of the sheer customization. The reason I have stopped playing is because of CS:GO (Nothing to do with APB: Reloaded itself). There are so many interesting things you can do on this game, for example spamming WASD to run in a circle and evade bullets like Neo from the Matrix! Or using LTL (Less than Lethal) Grenade launchers to stun everyone for days! There are quite a few cars, and in all honesty, there is no point in playing this game whatsoever without a premium sub. If you're not an Artist like me, than don't fret, you can still find music and cars designed by others for a fee. It may be difficult for you to place yourself in this game, or to have fun if you do not have friends who PC game, but don't worry! There are many clans and groups that play that aren't hacking, and some of them are really friendly. :D  Anyways, this games Guns (and many other items) are timed, which isn't really a problem TBH (I did eventually buy permanent weapons over a span of 3 years), and you definitely feel the prestige of getting higher and higher level. My brother plays this as well, all he does is create music to sell. It's worked out very well for him, he can buy anything on the game he wants aside from Joker content.  All in all, I recommend playing this game at least long enough to get to R100, hopefully you'll have a good time and enjoy the game to it's fullest by then. :)

This game has a great potential to be a fun little distraction, when having flashlights and lasers shone into your eyes is too 'realistic' for you, or when WoW is too 'click-to-win' for your taste.  Mixing MMO and TPS in a pretty strange mix, the action, customization, and open world feel you can find in this game have impressed me. For a free to play, pay to win game it turned out to be rather enjoyable even without transactions.  However, the only reason I can NOT recommend trying this game, is its match making system. You, as a new player, must not only understand your chosen role, criminal or enforcer, but also your role as fodder. The match maker feeds you to higher levels quite readily, and to make sure you, as the fodder, can't leave the trough it drops you into, you are not permitted to leave a mission once you've been pulled into it.  Feeding higher ranks isn't avoidable. You have cheap guns and no armor, they have very powerful guns and armor that grants them greater health than you. In a CQC fight between yourself, wielding an SMG made for CQC, and a high level enemy, wielding a high power rifle made for sniping, the higher level will win due to the fact their armor soaks your bullets, and your lack of armor doesn't soak their far stronger bullets.  Ultimately, the choice you must decide on before you pick up this game is this: Do you want to be a feeder, or do you want to be a competitor? If you chose the latter, hit the back button on the store browser and find another free game.

It's open world and fully explorable, with all kinds of weapon/armor upgrades and crafting involved. Basically like a dumbed down red dead redemption meets morrowind meets MMO. It's cool, worth the download, especially since it's f2p. 8/10

Personally, I really like this game, and have devoted quite a while into it. The patches and all do move along at a somewhat slow rate, given the small dev team, but I think its actually a really good game. I read some of the other reviews and I will address some of the issues mentioned.  Pay2Win- Basically every gun in the ARMAS Marketplace is a reskin of a gun you get from in-game progression, and the few execeptions have lots of downsides to balance their upsides. Anyone who claims that guns are p2w most likely hasn't gone to the cash shop and trialed the guns, which by the way, you can do, trialing all of the guns for 30minutes/3hours depending if you have premium membership. Really though, the in-game progression weapons are on par, or even better than their cash shop counterparts.  Hackers-  This community is so paranoid of hackers, its pretty much a given that either one person might seem like they are hacking, or you will get hackusated. Just realize that its possible that people are better than you, because some people have been around 4-5 years, since the start in RTW times.  Lag- At the time of this post, one of the districts, Waterfront, has been rather laggy, but they have been working on a fix for it, and the lag only occurs when there are more than 60 people per instance (excess people can move to a different instance to fight the lag, but sometimes they just don't)  Okay, and one more thing, its not as if you are paying $60 + DLC galore, its a free game. I understand this game might not be for everyone, mainly people that can't accept that people are better than them, and resort to calling people hackers or calling weapons p2w. Give it a shot, though, because it truly is pretty good quality for a f2p game.

APB: All Points Bulletin, was my first encounter with this game back in 2010. I first heard about it in 2009 on a podcast I used to listen to weekly and they talked about this game for a little while, what I got out of it was that it was nothing more than a GTA clone with bad car mechanics and ok'ish graphics. So naturarly I didn't give it a second thought until one of my friends who had just gone trough GTA4 and its DLCs on PC started to talk about it just weeks before release and wanted me to join in and get it, I thought why not as the idea behind the game was cool... Well, the idea was cool but the execution was horrible, poorly optimized, lag spikes and a bunch of glitches. I lived trough this mess for around 56 hours of gametime before I quit, then just a couple months later it was announced that the developer and the game itself would close down. Wow, it had not been out for a year even, and they where already closing it down. Though as I can remember so had it cost a stupid amount of money to develop, so I kinda see why. Then a little while later somebody bought the IP and announced that it was going f2p.  Anyways, fast forward to summer of 2011 when the open beta for APB: Reloaded started and I tested it again, this time the game actually played nice, though still not the best when it comes to optimization and server stability but I cranked out around 100 hours before I quit again. Then I tested it again just a few months ago and it was still the same, nothing had changed. Nothing.   Pros

Pay to Win, all the highest skilled players buy guns, gear, and cosmetics with real money to get an edge against F2P players. Spawnkilling and Camping is rampent, community chatbox is complete cancer, giving you an experience reminicient of Youtube Comments instead of a real multiplayer experience. Teamwork is required but doesn't exist with most players. Playing alone outside of missions actually gets you more money than in missions with less risk of meeting a P2W player.  Enforcers overpopulate most servers and have an edge on players.  Server-end Latency results in it feeling like it takes forever to kill players, shooting them dozens of times to kill them. But of course if you purchase a gun from the 'armas marketplace' you instantly play better at the game.  While the characters are interesting and fun looking, the ultimate result in this game is disappointing, and the combination of cancerous P2W methods, spawncamping, hackers, outdated graphics, and repetitive gameplay make this ultimately an old attempt at making a free to play GTA game, and you will have better luck just going and playing GTA5.  For Character customization, go to any current-era MMO game and you will be able to find similar if not better.  This game isn't worth the time nor the effort.

This game has the potential to be awesome but it sucks on so many levels. First off it is a massive grind, you have to invest a substantial amount of time into it to be able to unlock anything at all, even if you pay the monthly fee to increase your rates. On top of that you have a broken weapon system that leaves every weapon with an unrealistic niche forcing you to buy a ton of weapons to be able to fight in different areas of the map otherwise the guy with the weapon better tailored for that alleyway or that elevated highway is going to win regardless of how good he/you are.   The biggest flaw however is the ranking system in this game. It is absolutly impossible to play this game as a new player and have a decent time learning the game because the tiered ranking system apparently plays no role whatsoever in matchmaking. There are servers tiered for each rank on the list, but they are not locked for that rank so someone well beyond your skill level as judged by the game can join your server and will get matched against you in the matchmaking system every... single... game. It just isn't fun getting destroyed mission after mission by female avatars in knee stockings and miniskirts, or flat naked who have hours upon hours more invested in the game to unlock all of the guns and perks and cars and whatever else.   Game sucks, do yourself a favor and go get just cause 2 if you want a freeform driving multiplayer game, or world of warcraft if you want to spend hours of your life doing the same repetative â¥â¥â¥â¥ for hours on end to raise up in level.

APB: Reloaded has gone downhill significantly since it's Free-to-Play release. While it still retains a good feeling for the gunplay mechanics, the prevelance and overzealous pushing of the cash shop along with annoying players with 'subscribe now!' advertisements tends to get in the way.  Over time weapons have been tuned in such a way that significant advantages (especially in lower threat levels and ranks) are outright purchasable with real cash, and these aren't cheap. Permanent weapons can cost upwards of a full $40 if not more, but at least now they're able to be applied to all characters on an account for a premium.  Cheating is a very common problem these days, be it via hacks or gaming the threat/matchmaking system. With no real appropriate ladder, and the overwhelming amount of people who feel that if they aren't winning they aren't having fun; we find that more and more players will use every and any trick in the book and out of the book to win with illegitimate results.  If you can get over those issues though, and play APB:R without too much invested in it with a few friends, you can have an absolute blast be it chasing down criminal players or resisting arrest from enforcers.  The question here is whether or not APB:R is good enough to warrant still being alive, and that's a debatable answer.

Now I know my hours of gameplay for this game doesn't say much, but hear me out anyways.  APB:R is an open world MMO where the players could either be the criminals or the enforcers. The roles are quite self-explainatory   The gameplay itself is quite what you would expect from any other third-person game, run to cover, peep out, unload your guns, that or you could just jump out and spray your munition and pray that it lands on the target. The gameplay however isn't what fascinates me, it is the customization option that you apply to your ride or your player model. You can create your very own designs from scratch, whether or not it ends up as tattoo or a car decal, the endless possiblity of creation is simply just mind blowing (Provided that you unlock all the customization option). As someone who studies graphic designs, this is my nice cup of tea.   Note: Premium players can put in more customization items on their clothings/car/tattoos compared to f2p players.  Of course, since this is a free to play game there are in-game items that you can buy to give you an edge against your opposition. Personally however, I think this game is still reasonable even if you are a f2p player.  The only downside for me is probaly the community inside the game. I'm not sure about the other servers, but the server I'm currently residing in is just..just.... full of twelve years old who are uncapable of listening to reason and logic. Oh yeah. Overall its a pretty epic and unique Pvp open world game. Dont listen to all people that try to make it look bad just because they dont know how to be good at the game.  Its not pay2win! U can beat armas weapons very good with non cash weapons. The best weapons like Ntec, PMG, OCA and HVR are all FREE FOR IN GAME MONEY at contacts.  It just takes much time to learn the game (map knowledge, tactics, weapon control and more).   And its also NOT full of cheaters. Of course there are cheaters but its not even half that worse like in many other f2p games. This Game uses Fairfight Anti Cheat. Fairfight monitores how someone is playing (Check  FFBANS.ORG  to see most banned players from APB).  The customization possibilities of APB are just unique. U can almost make every design you want on your cars and clothing :) (Thats why it needs this high amount of RAM) Well about performance its not very optimized because its a old unreal engine version very heavy modified.  Engine upgrade for PC should come after they released the Ps4 version on which they currently working on. But it can run well at 40-60fps when u own a good 4 core Cpu, 8 GB of Ram (its waaay more CPU and RAM intense than GPU intense) and a Gpu with 1 - 1,5Gb of Vram. Of course it depends on your Graphic settings. You can make more detailed graphics Settings with Advanced APB Launcher (search APB forums to find the download for it)..   So give it a try and start learning and u will see its just great.
